items.title: Get rid of -fsanitize=undefined for tests
items.body: Unconditionally adding -fsanitize=undefined breaks compilation on systems using musl, or systems with sanitizers disabled at GCC configure time.

items.title: Mouse, keyboard, and music from headsets
items.body:
Hi guys,
i just want to say that you are great and the noise suppressor is great plugin. Maybe even better than the paid Goyo Supertone clear.

I was just wondering if it is possible to fix picking up sounds from my mouse, keyboard and music from my headphones when I am talking. When I am not talking the gate is perfect, but when I am talking people can hear my mouse, keyboard, and sound from my headphones?

Currently i am using VAD Threshold - 60, VAD Grace period - 20 (default), and Retroactive VAD - 10 since otherwise it is cutting same of my words.

items.title: Latency changes between relaunches, no delay compensation
items.body:
I really don't know how vst development works, but I know that most plugins support plugin delay compensation, meaning the plugin reports to the host how much latency it's generating at any given moment and the host can then adjust everything to be in sync according to that

This plugin doesn't do that for me, but that can easily be done manually (if it's the vst2 that is. The vst3 for some reason re-desyncs itself as i near toward a better sync latency offset...)

As for the vst2, the real issue is that this latency varies between restarts of the plugin or host. It doesn't seem to change over time during the session though. So i'll have to go and manually count samples to get the right latency every single time I restart my host

RNNoise absolutely works best when mixed with the raw (or in my case, still somewhat processed) voice audio, so layering them for live recording is a must for decent quality

Info:
Windows 10, FL Studio 20.8.1, vst2 and vst3 tested v1.03
All 3 parameters are at 0 for me

items.title: Game audio issues
items.body:
I installed the plugin via Equalizer APO and it worked perfectly in terms of making my mic static/white noise go away.

The problem that I am facing, however, is that it seems to be applying to my in game audio setting for warzone as well. I have some equalizations set up via Equalizer APO/Hesuvi that allow me to hear footsteps in game as well.

The noise suppression plug in only works when I install it in my first configuration... anywhere else and I still get mic static. When I use the plug in and start the game it seems that the suppression effect applies to my in game audio as well...essentially any in game noises that dont reach my threshhold are eliminated. This is forcing me to chose between using my in game audio settings or having a clear sounding mic.

I am using Linux Mint 21.2, Kernel version is 5.19.0-46-generic, Desktop Environment is Cinnamon. I will try to provide more info upon request.

Going to describe what I did to install it in case I was being dumb and misunderstood the instructions, causing the issue. 
I downloaded the .zip, extracted the folder to my Home folder, created _/home/leaderofthe00fkins/.config/pipewire/pipewire.conf.d/99-input-denoising.conf_ and pasted the configuration. From the text in the guide it seems like, essentially, a new audio input device should have been created with the name "Noise Canceling source".

My issue is that no Input device was created after following the instructions. There was no output in the terminal when using the pipewire restart command. items.title: Incorrect install paths
items.body:
For example, [this](https://github.com/werman/noise-suppression-for-voice/blob/master/src/juce_plugin/CMakeLists.txt#L97) line should be:
> install(DIRECTORY ${CMAKE_LIBRARY_OUTPUT_DIRECTORY}/rnnoise.vst3 DESTINATION lib/vst3)

cmake's install instruction expects relative paths as DESTINAION, otherwise it installs into ```$PREFIX$PREFIX```.

The same problem exists with ```LV2``` plugin.

items.title: Add target.object to capture.props in exemplary pipewire config
items.body:
The readme currently gives an exemplary pipewire config using the filter-chain module, which really helps when setting this up. The filter chain simply listens on the default source, which might not be the source you actually want it to use.
To get around this, you can specify a target source as input for the filter-chain (thanks to @licentiapoetica for figuring this out):
```
capture.props = {
    node.name =  "capture.rnnoise_source"
    node.passive = true
    audio.rate = 48000
    target.object = "alsa_input.usb-Logitech_Logitech_G930_Headset-00.mono-fallback"
}
```

I propose to either add this to the example or at least note it somewhere, so that other users don't face the same issue as I did.

See also: https://github.com/werman/noise-suppression-for-voice/issues/162#issuecomment-1677979108

I'm a pt-br speaker (not sure if it's relevant). And words starting with the "S" sound get a cut when they start the phrase. Words like "SIM" (yes) and "CERTO" (right, sure) become "IM" and "ERTO".

Even in english, the word "sure" gets a quick cut on the "S" (maybe my pronunciation is not correct?). 

I was wondering if there is a way to work it out, to reduce the "deesser" a little.

items.title: Using the Retroactive VAD breaks VAD Grace Period.
[Windows 11 - EqualizerAPO 1.3 - plugin version 1.02] VST plugin not working while using Discrod
items.body:
### Problem
The VST plugin behaves in a weird way while using Discord (only tested with mic test in the settings menu). When I enable the VST plugin in EqualizerAPO, noise is not really suppressed, everything is just a little bit more muffled and after I start speaking, even the muffling goes away and it sounds like the plugin is not even enabled.  

But here is the weird part. The plugin works everywhere else that I have tested without any problems. I tried basically the same test but in the Windows settings (the "Listen to this device" in Sound settings) and it works as expected. I also tried the default windows sound recorder app and the noise suppression also worked perfectly as expected.

### Testing
I tried to see if maybe Discord somehow manages to crash the plugin, but it does not appear like it does. Going immediately back and forth between the Discord mic check and Windows "Listen to this device" check (enabling Dis. mic check, try speaking, disable, enable Windows check, speak, disable), the noise suppression works in the Windows check, but not in Discord. So it does not appear like Discord crashes the plugin, because the noise suppression immediately works in a different program.

I also checked if Discord is not somehow bypassing EqualizerAPO, but I don't think so because I have been using the older version of the plugin (version 0.91) and it worked flawlessly. I also tried to switch between the new version (1.02) and the old version (0.91) on the fly while listening to my voice on Discord and the old version worked as expected while the new version did what I have already described.

items.title: Pipewire Setup, affecting output, crackling sound
items.body:
I followed the Pipewire section, and I got it working successfully. The input is a USB microphone, and the output is to a USB DAC.
If I select the the "Noise cancelling source" in audio settings, the audio cancellation works great, both the fan and AC sound is suppressed, even when I am speaking. But when playing music, or in Discord voice, or any sound really, there is a crackling sound that I can hear, along with the audio. If I select the USB microphone as the output instead of the Noise cancelling source, the crackling sound stops immediately.

Software Setup
OS: EndeavourOS Linux x86_64
Kernel: 5.18.5-arch1-1
DE: Plasma 5.25.0

items.title: Make 200ms VAD grace period variable
items.body:
First of all let me say how awesome this plugin is! :star2: 
I've been experimenting with it on Raspberry Pi 4 for [SEPIA Open Assistant](https://sepia-framework.github.io/) using Pulseaudio and I'm getting great results with acceptable CPU load (about 40% on one core).

The problem I'm experiencing though is that wake-word recognition gets worse and I think this is because of the aggressive VAD filtering leading to a few missing samples at the beginning of the wake-word. Using something like "Hey hey SEPIA" instead of "Hey SEPIA" for example seems to be a partial "workaround".

Is it possible to make the VAD grace period (`k_vadGracePeriodSamples` I believe) variable and maybe introduce some parameter to keep a few more frames at the onset? Latency is not a big problem for the input so maybe one could buffer a few frames (50ms ?!)

items.title: Usage instructions  / Sensible Pulseaudio names.
items.body:
Thanks for this awesome piece of software! :-) 

This script should work for most typical pulseaudio setups with only one sound card.

It also overrides the confusing default PulseAudio names "Null Output" "Monitor of Null Output" etc. with more user friendly ones.

It creates both usable mic sources so users can choose whatever shows up in the software they want to use the mic with.

Feel free to modify as you see fit or if you need me to make any changes or make it more user friendly let me know.

Usage: 
`pa-denoise.sh /path/to/librnnoise_ladspa.so `

```
#!/bin/bash
RNNOISEPATH=$1
MICSOURCE=`pactl list sources short|grep input |awk '{print $2}'|head -1`
echo "Using ${MICSOURCE} as raw mic input. If you have multiple sound cards override the value for MICSOURCE in the script."
pacmd load-module module-null-sink sink_name=mic_denoised_out rate=48000
pacmd update-sink-proplist mic_denoised_out device.description='"Denoised Mic"'
pacmd update-source-proplist mic_denoised_out.monitor device.description='"Denoised Mic Monitor"'
pacmd load-module module-ladspa-sink sink_name=mic_raw_in sink_master=mic_denoised_out label=noise_suppressor_mono plugin=${RNNOISEPATH} control=50
pacmd load-module module-loopback source=${MICSOURCE} sink=mic_raw_in channels=2 source_dont_move=true sink_dont_move=true
pacmd load-module module-remap-source source_name=denoised master=mic_denoised_out.monitor channels=2
pacmd update-source-proplist denoised device.description='"Alt Denoised Mic Monitor"'
```

items.title: pulse audio questions.
items.body:
- How do I get this working for kubuntu 20.04? I am having trouble following the README
- Is it possible to get this to loop through all devices?
- Is it possible to use existing devices instead of creating a bunch of new devices? 
- can you also answer these questions in the README? 
```
.include /etc/pulse/default.pa

load-module module-null-sink sink_name=mic_denoised_out rate=48000
load-module module-ladspa-sink sink_name=mic_raw_in sink_master=mic_denoised_out label=noise_suppressor_mono plugin="~/.local/bin/ladspa/librnnoise_ladspa.so" control=50
load-module module-loopback source=your_mic_name sink=mic_raw_in channels=1 source_dont_move=true sink_dont_move=true latency_msec=1 label=noise_suppressor_stereo channels=2
load-module module-remap-source source_name=denoised master=mic_denoised_out.monitor channels=1


set-default-source mic_denoised_out.monitor
```

items.title: Modifying Settings and sample noise.
Can I use this filter but on an output source and not an input one?
items.body:
I'm trying to filter out the Discord output.
I mean, I want to hear only my friends's voices and not their keyboard/mouse clicks, etc.

I'm trying something like this:
```
#!/usr/bin/env sh

output_sink=$(pacmd stat |grep -o -P "(?<=Default sink name: ).*")

pacmd load-module module-null-sink sink_name=discord_denoised_out rate=48000
pacmd update-sink-proplist discord_denoised_out device.description=DiscordFilter
pacmd load-module module-ladspa-sink sink_name=discord_raw_in sink_master=discord_denoised_out label=noise_suppressor_mono plugin=/path/to/lib/bin/ladspa/librnnoise_ladspa.so control=80
pacmd load-module module-loopback latency_msec=1 source=discord_denoised_out.monitor sink=$output_sink
```

Then in PulseAudio Volume Controll I choose DiscordFilter for the discord playback but I can hear any difference.

Am I doing something wrong, and is this possible at all?
